title: Godfrey Rampling
text:
Godfrey Lionel Rampling (14 May 1909 – 20 June 2009) was an <a href="England">English</a> <a href="Sport%20of%20athletics">athlete</a> and <a href="British%20Army">army</a> officer who competed for <a href="Great%20Britain">Great Britain</a> in the <a href="1932%20Summer%20Olympics">1932 Summer Olympics</a> and in the <a href="1936%20Summer%20Olympics">1936 Summer Olympics</a>. He <a href="centenarian">turned 100</a> on 14 May 2009 and was the oldest living British Olympian at the time of his death.
Life and career.
Rampling was born in <a href="Blackheath%2C%20London">Blackheath, London</a>, the son of Gertrude Anne (Taylor) and Horace Johnson Rampling, a costumier. Rampling won the British <a href="Amateur%20Athletic%20Association">AAA</a> championships in the in 1931 and 1934.
At the <a href="1932%20Summer%20Olympics">1932 Summer Olympics</a>, Rampling was fourth in his semifinal in the <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%201932%20Summer%20Olympics%20-%20Men%27s%20400%20metres">individual 400 metre event</a> and didn't reach the final, but ran the anchor leg to help the British 4 × 400 m <a href="Relay%20race">relay</a> team win the silver medal, behind the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>.
At the <a href="1934%20British%20Empire%20Games">1934 British Empire Games</a> in London, Rampling won the , and helped the English 4×440 yards relay team to capture the gold medal.
At the 1936 <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a> <a href="Olympic%20Games">Olympics</a>, Rampling was again fourth in the semifinals of <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%201936%20Summer%20Olympics%20-%20Men%27s%20400%20metres">400 metre competition</a> and ran the second leg on the British 4 × 400 m relay team which won the gold medal.
Rampling was a <a href="Lieutenant-Colonel%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Lieutenant Colonel</a> in the <a href="Royal%20Artillery">Royal Artillery</a>, attached to <a href="NATO">NATO</a>, until retiring in 1958 after 29 years service.
He married Isabel Anne (née Gurteen; 1918–2001); their daughter <a href="Charlotte%20Rampling">Charlotte</a> became a noted model and film actress. He was, as of October 2007, the last surviving male athletics medallist from the <a href="1932%20Summer%20Olympics">1932 Summer Olympics</a> and the last male gold medallist in athletics from the <a href="1936%20Summer%20Olympics">1936 Summer Olympics</a>.
Rampling was Britain's oldest living Olympic Gold medallist and also oldest living Olympic competitor. He celebrated his centenary with his family on 14 May 2009 at <a href="Bushey">Bushey</a> in <a href="Hertfordshire">Hertfordshire</a>.
Rampling died in his sleep aged 100 on 20 June 2009.
